<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 165, 235]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 259]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[724, 220, 720, 235]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[867, 220, 901, 235]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[668, 220, 720, 235]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[51, 262, 80, 280]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 279, 230, 292]]<|/det|> MATHEMATICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[827, 279, 905, 294]]<|/det|> 9790/11 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 304, 311, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[765, 305, 905, 319]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 328, 905, 343]]<|/det|> 1 hour 50 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 386, 391, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: List of formulae (MF19) <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 451, 761, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 565, 496]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 867, 544]]<|/det|> - If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 482, 575]]<|/det|> - You should use a calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 881, 590]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 854, 620]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 669, 214, 680]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 683, 388, 698]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 75 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 714]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 74, 565, 91]]<|/det|>
BLANK PAGE

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 602, 105]]<|/det|>
1 Solve the equation \(6 \sin \theta=1+\frac{2}{\sin \theta}\) for \(-180^{\circ}<\theta<180^{\circ}\) ï¼Ž

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 921, 107]]<|/det|>
2 The equation of a curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}=4(2 x-5)^{3}-9 x^{\frac{1}{2}}\). The curve passes through the point \(A\left(4,-\frac{11}{2}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 142, 611, 161]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the gradient of the normal to the curve at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 482, 399, 501]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
3 The third term of a geometric progression is 18 and the sum of the first three terms is 26 . It is given that the common ratio is negative.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 840, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the tenth term of the progression. Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 737, 634, 754]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the exact value of the sum to infinity of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
4

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 91, 703, 306]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 318, 874, 341]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y=5 x^{\frac{3}{2}}-20 x\) and the line with equation \(y=x-16\). The \(x\)-coordinates of the points of intersection of the curve and line are 1 and 16 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 369, 631, 387]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region between the curve and the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
5 (a) Find the first three terms, in ascending powers of \(x\), in the expansion of each of the following expressions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 117, 267, 138]]<|/det|>
(i) \((2-p x)^{5}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[152, 333, 269, 364]]<|/det|>
(ii) \(\left(1-\frac{1}{2} x\right)^{4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 556, 918, 587]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that the coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \((2-p x)^{5}\left(1-\frac{1}{2} x\right)^{4}\) is 93 , find the possible values of the constant \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 918, 96]]<|/det|>
6 The equation of a curve is \(2 x^{2}-k x y+2=0\) and the equation of a line is \(y=p x+3\), where \(k\) and \(p\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 125, 918, 142]]<|/det|>
(a) Given that \(k=2\) and \(p=11\), find the coordinates of the points of intersection of the curve and the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
(b) Given instead that \(p=4\), find the set of values of \(k\) for which the curve and the line do not intersect.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 465, 108]]<|/det|>
7 The equation of a curve is \(y=4 x^{2}+\frac{9}{x^{2}}-8\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) A point \(P\) is moving along the curve in such a way that its \(y\)-coordinate is decreasing at 5 units per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 168, 736, 184]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which the \(x\)-coordinate of point \(P\) is changing when \(x=2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 811, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the coordinates of the stationary points of the curve and determine their nature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 76, 898, 97]]<|/det|>
8 The circle with equation \(x^{2}+y^{2}-6 x+10 y-27=0\) intersects the line \(x=-2\) at the points \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 109, 867, 126]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the triangle formed by the tangents to the circle at \(P\) and \(Q\), and the line \(x=-2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 90]]<|/det|>
9

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 87, 659, 251]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 87, 450, 104]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[523, 146, 566, 160]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[533, 206, 580, 222]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 228, 657, 243]]<|/det|>
  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 269, 918, 286]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(A B C\) of a circle with centre \(A\) and radius \(r \mathrm{~cm}\). The angle \(B A C\) is \(\alpha\) radians, where \(0<\alpha<\frac{1}{2} \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 314, 885, 335]]<|/det|>
(a) It is given that the area of the triangle \(A B C\) is \(4 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\) and the area of the sector \(A B C\) is \(8 \alpha \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 349, 489, 366]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of the shaded segment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(b) It is given instead that the length of the chord \(B C\) is \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} r \mathrm{~cm}\) but the area of the triangle \(A B C\) is still \(4 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 138, 830, 157]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded segment. Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 405, 91]]<|/det|>
10 The functions \(f\) and \(g\) are defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[362, 101, 637, 153]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{ll}
\mathrm{f}(x)=\sqrt{x} & \text { for } x \geqslant 0 \\
\mathrm{~g}(x)=3 \sqrt{x+2}-5 & \text { for } x \geqslant-2
\end{array}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 914, 183]]<|/det|>
(a) Describe fully a sequence of transformations which transforms the graph of \(y=\mathrm{f}(x)\) to the graph of \(y=\mathrm{g}(x)\). You should make clear the order in which the transformations are applied.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 583, 796, 845]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 860, 451, 877]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y=\mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 888, 824, 908]]<|/det|>
(b) On the diagram sketch the graph of \(y=\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\) together with any relevant mirror line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 396, 97]]<|/det|>
(c) Find an expression for \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 353, 335, 374]]<|/det|>
(d) State the range of \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 449, 344, 466]]<|/det|>
The function h is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[394, 478, 603, 497]]<|/det|>
\[
\mathrm{h}(x)=x-2 \quad \text { for } x \geqslant 0 .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 507, 366, 528]]<|/det|>
(e) Find the value of \(\mathrm{g}^{-1} \mathrm{~h}(4)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 724, 631, 743]]<|/det|>
(f) Explain why the composite function \(\mathrm{hg}^{-1}\) cannot be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
